1. Increase the number of signatories by 5%. 2. At least 4 newsletters published and 4 welcome webinars and 4 COP and COE training. 3. Participation in 3 knowledge exchange activities such as workshops, webinars, publications. 4. At least 2 members of the Secretariat participating in UNGC Global and Regional Meetings. 5. Work with at least 4 UNGC platforms in Brazil. 6. At least 3 activities per Thematic Group. 7. At least 6 UN Agencies involved with the Local Network activities. 8. At least 10 members participating in Thematic Groups. 9. At least 30% of women participating in Thematic Groups activities. 10. 70% of budget execution according to Project Board and CBPG guidance. 11. 100% of team members participating in training or capacity building events. 12. 40% of women in CBPG and CBPG Board. 13. At least 2 collaboration processes between Local Network and Government Agencies.Participate in at least 2 public policy development process.

1. There are 6% more members at LN Brazil, even with the implementation of the new business model, in which companies with annual revenue higher than USD 50 million have to contribute financially. The number of payee members increase 150%, increasing the financial sustainability of the network. 2. There is a new communications plan and the new targets on it were updated, referring now to social networks and traditional media. From December 2017 until October 2018, Global Compact Network Brazil conquered a greater reach in social networks (25% new followers on facebook, 36% on twitter and 105% on LinkedIn) and in traditional media outlets (126 news). Furthermore, 9 webinars are expected to happen this year (there were 6 until November). 3. At least four exchange activities are happening this year. I. Network Brazil was chosen to be part of a Anti-Corruption Collective Action, funded by Siemens and led by UNGC, that also involves the LNs from Japan, Kenya and Nigeria; II. There is a consultant from Pacific Institute/ CEO Water Mandate leading the WG on Water and Sanitation in the local initiative, and all the activities related to water stewardship; III. For COP 24, LN Brazil is organizing an event alongside the United Nations Office for South-South Cooperation, involving other LNs from Asia and Africa; IV. LN Brazil is in constant contact with LN Colombia in order to learn more about their participation in the country’s VNR; 4. GCNB's secretariat was present in the XVI Annual Local Network Forum and in the Making Global Goals Local Business, that happened in April in Buenos Aires, Argentina, and reunited more than 100 Local Network Contact Points. The secretariat was also in Colombia for the LAC Regional Meeting of the Local Networks, in November. Integrants of the secretariat and representatives of companies members of the network were also present in at least four relevant international high-level events: the High Level Political Forum (July, NY); the World Water Week (August, Stockholm, Sweden); the 2018 Forum on Business and Human Rights (November, Geneva, Switzerland); and COP 24 (December, Poland). 4.a In 2018, LN Brazil has strengthened its participation in the GCO decision making process and and has amplified its relationship with other LNs. The Local Network executive secretary is now the representative of the LNs in the Board of UNGC, co-chair of the Local Network Council and the Chair of the Regional Network Council LAC. 5. LN Brazil works with 7 Action Platforms: Breakthrough Innovation for the SDGs; Reporting on the SDGs; Financial Innovation for the SDGs; Pathways to Low-Carbon and Resilient Development; Decent Work in Global Supply Chains; Peace, Justice and Strong Institutions; Water Security through Stewardship. 6. There are at 3 activities per WG, there are 30 in total (amongst collective actions, publications projects and trainings) 7. LN Brazil has engaged with 9 UN agencies: UNHCR, UN Women, ACNUDH, ILO, IOM, UNFPA, UNOSSC, beyond UNDP and UNGC. 8. The average of participants in the WGs is 30 people; 9. The average of women participating actively in the meetings is 60%; 10. The forecast of the budget execution for 2018 is 87%; 11. 100% of team members have completed their UNDP mandatory courses and are also participating in events and small training related to their field areas. 12. 80% of the board is composed by women and 62% the CBPG. 13.Network Brasil integrates the National Commission for the SDGs (CNODS), from the Secretary of Government, and also the Technical Committee of the Low Carbon Industry, Ministry of Industry, Foreign Trade and Services. In addition, it has partnership with other government agencies.

description.narrative: Access to sustainable energy for host communities through the implementation of renewable energy systems; and provision of sustainable solid waste waste solutions.

participating-org.narrative: University Hospital Center Notre Dame des Secours

description.narrative: first-order administrative division

activity-description.narrative: Provision of renewable energy applications for vulnerable host communities in Aakkar area.

provider-org.narrative: University Hospital Center Notre Dame des Secours
University Hospital Center Notre Dame des Secours
University Hospital Center Notre Dame des Secours

description.narrative: -Availability of end-use renewable energy units -Number of persons with increased access to energy

comment.narrative: Limited electricity supply and limited application of renewable energy technologies at host communities.

NLD II Energy (A4): - The 43 low voltage transformers installed in Bekaa and South are energised and being monitored. - The 12 installed PV systems (including the 2 for the WWTPs) are working well and are being monitored. - Installation of 300 home systems in households in Dinniyeh is completed. - Additional 100 home systems in Dinniyeh and Bekaa are completed. In total 400 home systems were installed. - The rehabilitation of 15 sites (public schools) are completed. - Additional 4 sites (public schools) were selected and rehabilitation completed. - Upgrading briquetting plants in Bkassine and Andqe is completed. - Installation of Rapid Shutdown system at Dar el Salam completed. - Production of a Video showcasing all the implementations under NLD II energy component is completed. - Rehabilitation and maintenance of 8 public schools.
'NDLII Solid Waste: -North Bekaa: the location of the site was changed but remained in the same target area; the excavation works have started for the construction of the sanitary landfill (as a component of an ISWM facilities) to serve the union of municipalities of Deir Al Ahmar and some other villages (total of 14 villages); -The EIA study is underway; the scoping public hearing event was held on the 26th of June 2019. -Bar Elias: The sanitary landfill cell is constructed, lined and isolated and handed over to Bar Elias Municipality. - Hezzerta: The project has completed the necessary studies and assessment for the closure/rehabilitation of existing dumpsite; the team is currently seeking possible funds for the closure/rehabilitation. -ISWM Lebanon Road map: the ISWM Road map was approved by the CoM. The project team is currently supporting the MoE in the development of the road map's legal and technical requirements.
Solid Waste funded by the Government of Japan: - Design of the material recovery facility is on-going with the technical consultants - The team is working closely with LOST for the development and implementation of awareness raising campaign on sorting at source in the selected villages in order to build the capacity of the local communities (total of 14 villages).

NLD II Energy: - Monitoring the implementation and commissioning of 40 transformers; - Monitoring the implementation and commission the installation of 11 PV systems in selected sites; - The implementation of 2 biogas sites is assessed.
LRF Street lighting: - The installation of 320 PV street lighting is completed at selected sites (10 - 15 villages).
NDL II Solid Waste: - Completion of the "Sorting at Source" awareness raising campaign for the targeted villages within the lake union of municipalities (west Bekaa), construction of the recyclables sorting facility, and the provision of bins and equipment. - The municipalities are trained on environmental management; - The turnkey construction of the North Baalbek sorting or lanfilling facility is completed and commissioned; - The construction of the Bar Elias sanitary landfill cell (pending the CoM's decision to include Bar Elias on the list to profit from the EU funds for the operation of the SWM plant) is initiated.

Solid Waste intervention in North Baalbeck: - Complete the design and construction of the Material Recovery Facility (MRF) in Deir Al Ahmar -Implement awareness raising campaign on sorting at source in the selected villages with LOST -Procure bins and refuse collection vehicles in coordination with LOST -Conduct a feasibility study of environmental technologies for non-recyclable waste in Lebanon
Plastic Waste: - prepare project document - initiate the activities

Solid Waste intervention in North Baalbeck: After the completion of the awareness campaign on sorting at source in the selected villages, the project is currently procuring the needed trucks for the respective municipalities in order to enhance the waste collection. Five trucks will be provided as follows: three for the union of Deir Al Ahmar municipalities, one for Chlifa and one for Yammouneh.
The project has completed the data collection of the phase 4 of the plastic study, and is currently in the final stage of the assessment. The study has entered its final phase and is now assessing the general applicability of magneto pyrolysis treatment and its application in Lebanon.
Based on bidding process that was conducted by the project team, a contracting company was awarded the MRF construction. Due to the COVID-19 pandemic and the security and economical country status, the work on site was significantly delayed; however, the team was able to undertake the project first phase and the construction work is expected to be completed by the end of June 2021.
Plastic Waste: The team has initiated the financial and economic assessment for the plastic sector in Lebanon. The project has identified the potential beneficiaries in the private sector for upgrading recycling systems in Lebanon. Currently the team is finalizing the evaluation. In addition, the project has initiated the support for 2 NGOs for upgrading recycling systems. (including MoE, Association of Industries, etc.) to ensure the proper implementation of the project.

description.narrative: Energy Efficiency and Renewable Energy for Sustainable Water Management in Turkmenistan
first-order administrative division
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: Extent of change in energy efficiency (UNDP Integrated Results and Resources Framework indicator 1.5.2) – specifically, consumption of electricity and fossil fuels and associated emissions of CO2 from water management per hectare of irrigated land Consumption of water per hectare of irrigated land Hectares of land protected and/or reclaimed from salinization Implementation of national and sub-national plans for IWRM (UNDP Integrated Results and Resources Framework indicator 2.5.2). State and private investment in new and efficient integrated water management Number of people benefitting from new and improved water management systems

comment.narrative:
9 million GJ/year and approximately 6.9 MtCO2/year from water management, including non-agricultural uses
24 billion m3 per year of water consumption for agriculture 2 million hectares of irrigated land 69 percent of irrigated land is moderately to severely salinized; approximately 200 million hectares are severely salinized Water codex adopted in 2004, but no supporting regulations nor regional/local plans for implementation of IWRM or energy efficiency in the water sector

Output targets 1.1. - 300 ha of land protected or reclaimed from salinisation as a result of demonstration projects Output target 2.2: - 2 production lines established (one for geomembrane and one for hexagonal precast concrete slabs) Output targets 3.1. At least 1 velayat Integrated Water Distribution and Management Plan developed and submitted for approval, recommendations are developed for other 2 velayats Output targets 3.2. - Key stakeholders/institutions with relevant mandates trained - 90% positive feedback from training participants received Output target 4.1: At least 3 secondary legislative acts related to irrigation infrastructure incl. pump audits, crop-specific irrigation norms, and water/energy saving practices to lead to GHG emission reduction developed and submitted for approval.

Result 1.1: As a result of the reporting year activities and previous years reclamation works, ameliorative condition of all arable lands of 145 ha Geokdepe site was improved. In addition, at the whole territory of green polygon the cross sections of open drainage collectors were cleared of weeds. Reconstruction of the collector-drainage canals completed back in 2016 allowed the entire territory to provide the necessary drainage of excess groundwater and lower its level, thereby eliminating the possibility of secondary salinization of soils. It became possible not only to collect collector-drainage water on green polygon, but also to improve the quality of collector-drainage water of neighbouring lands of an area of almost 270 hectares. In addition, operation of collectors 2D-3-6 and GKS-2-1 led to a decrease in the level of groundwater in adjacent neighbouring lands (at 70-80 m distance from the edge of the collectors) with a total area of 18.5 hectares. All these activities allowed to exceed the target.
Result 2.2: not achieved but it is in progress. Based on the recommendations of the International Consultant in irrigation canals, lining types suitable for climatic and soil conditions of Turkmenistan, and using local materials, were identified (water-proof membrane protected by an intermediate layer of sand and a layer of hexagonal slabs). The EERE project has already purchased 1,000 formworks for precast hexagonal concrete slabs. The procurement of a HDPE (waterproof membrane) extrusion line (to produce membranes with thickness of up to 1 mm) is in progress. Due to Covid-19 related constraints the delivery of equipment is expected in February 2021.
Result 3.1: not achieved but it is in progress. Project prepared 1st edition of a methodology for the development of on-farm and inter-farm water use plans and demonstrated it to national water specialists and received several comments from State Water Committee. Recently, project addressed all comments based on the 2018-2020 research results. 2nd edition of a methodology has passed the initial examination and was re-submitted to the State Water Committee for approval. Approval is expected on March-April 2021. During 2021, project plans to complete the development of the final version of the Water-use Planning Methodology. Therefore, 1 comprehensive plan for water use and water distribution at the velayat level will be developed and submitted for approval, and recommendations for the other 2 velayats will be developed.
Result 3.2 achieved: Over 360 national specialists representing Water Committee, Ministry of Agriculture and Nature Protection, Water Design Institute, students of Agricultural University and farmers have been trained locally and abroad since the beginning of the project in various topics related to rational water management, energy efficient irrigation techniques, pump maintenance, IWRM and SLM. Positive feedback rate from training participants is over 90%.
Result 4.1 achieved: The regulatory documents in the field of integrated management and protection of water resources were developed, agreed with the interested ministries and institutions, and submitted for approval with a total of 9 documents. These documents have been prepared considering the use of modern water and energy saving technologies in the agricultural and water sectors of the country to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. Also, the national partner was presented with the “Regulations on territorial water management organizations, water protection zones and coastal water protection zones of water bodies”. The newly developed editions of Construction Norms of Turkmenistan "Amelioration systems and structures" and an updated version of its application "Operation of irrigation and drainage systems", as well as Construction norms "Instructions for the design and construction of anti-seepage devices made of polyethylene (polymer) film for artificial reservoirs (watercourses)" were submitted to the Ministry of Construction and Architecture.

Output targets 1.1.- 300 ha of land protected or reclaimed from salinisation as a result of demonstration projects Output targets 1.2: - 20 percent energy saving achieved by replacement and/or fixing of old pumps Output target 1.3: 1100 people directly benefiting from measures on renewable-energy water supply in remote locations Output targets 2.1:- At least 1 similar project initiated in other similar (or mountainous areas) districts of Akhal and Balkan velayats of Turkmenistan. Output target 2.2: - Testing of at least three types of materials for canal linings and pipes. Initiation of mass production of new materials and/or cost reduction by 20 percent of mass-producing existing materials, involving at least two types of products.- Domestic production and installation expanded by 50 percent for at least two types of technologies for canal linings, pipelines, or other materials to reduce losses of water in transit. New lining of at least 400 km of canals. Reduction of water losses from newly lined canals by more than 50 percent. Output targets 3.1. At least 3 velayat Integrated Water Distribution Plans developed and submitted for approval, recommendations are developed for other 2 velayats (Lebap and Balkan) Output indicators 3.2. - Key stakeholders/institutions with relevant mandates involved trained jointly by the MAWE/Project - 90% positive feedback from training participants Output target 4.1: At least 3 acts related to pump audits, crop-specific irrigation norms, and water/energy saving practices (incl. irrigation infrastructure) to lead to GHG emission reduction developed and adopted in support of the new Water Code. Output target 4.3: There is a formal commitment of the government to allocate resources for demonstrated by the project technologies (e.g. inclusion in state-funded programmes and budgets) (Yes/No).

Results of Output targets 1.1.- Result not achieved, but progressing: In 2017 the project started reclamation of the area of 110 ha at Geokdepe research site. Land rehabilitation and salinity reduction process normally takes several years, so project will be monitoring salinity level throughout the project lifetime. Besides, in 2019 improved efficiency of municipal water supply in the town of Kaahka led to water savings that was used by local residents for reclamation of around 300 ha and sowing traditional crops. Results of Output targets 1.2.- Result not achieved, but progressing: Five physically worn obsolete pumps were replaced by brand new energy efficient ones in 2019. Based on the average energy specifications of baseline pump-sets (around 100 kW) and new pumps (40 kW), it is expected to achieve over 50% energy saving. The monitoring over energy consumption and productivity indicators is conducted and concrete results will be shared during next reporting. Results of Output targets 1.3.- Result achieved: The project completed installation of photovoltaic solar panels in three villages of Karakum desert to power water withdrawal from wells and purification/desalination of water in one of the villages. The total number of beneficiaries exceeded 1200 people. Results of Output targets 2.1.- Result not achieved, but progressing: Estimate based on actual performance of gravity driven pipeline displays up to 50% of water economy. Lifetime direct GHG emission reductions from operation of the combined water supply system in Kaakhka town are anticipated at 15,694 tCO2. Given its high replication potential in the country, a dialogue with the government will continue to upscale this water-energy nexus effect. Results of Output targets 2.2.- Result not achieved, but progressing: Under the guidance of National and International Experts, the project tested three types of canal lining materials and pipes. As a result of testing, lining with HDPE membrane protected by hexagonal concrete slabs was selected as the most effective one. The project purchased and delivered to the plant of State Water Committee over 1000 forms for production of hexagonal concrete slabs. Currently the project is trying to purchase and install membrane producing extrusion line at the same plant of State Water Committee. Results of Output targets 3.1.- Result not achieved, but progressing: The project developed methodology on development of inter-farm water use plans and demonstrated it to national water specialists through the seminar. The project plans to test the methodology on the farms of selected private farmers. The outcome of these activities will be used for further works on development of integrated regional sustainable water management plans with consideration of SLM at the level of etraps (districts). Results of Output targets 3.2.- Result achieved: Over 280 national specialists representing Water Committee, Ministry of Agriculture and Nature Protection, Water Design Institute and farmers have been trained locally and abroad since the beginning of the project in various topics related to rational water management, energy efficient irrigation techniques, pump maintenance and SLM. Positive feedback rate from training participants is over 90%. Results of Output targets 4.1.- Result not achieved, but progressing: The project developed four regulatory acts to support Water Code, including (i) operational regulations for pump stations; (ii) regulation for scheduled preventive maintenance and repair of water systems and facilities; (iii) technical regulations of irrigation infrastructure; and (iv) technical regulations of drainage infrastructure. The documents are currently under consideration of the State Committee of Water Management. Results of Output targets 4.3.- Result achieved: In 2019 the government adopted the National Program for the Development of Agriculture of Turkmenistan for 2019-2025, which, in addition to traditional agricultural activities, also envisages application of water saving irrigation technologies (drip, sprinklers), improvement of land reclamation techniques (laser land levelling) and other issues to improve the country's irrigated agriculture sector in the medium term. It is planned to spend 6.8 billion manat (more than 1.9 billion US dollars) for the implementation of this program, mainly from the state budget of the country.

Output targets 1.1. - Demonstration project achieves comparable yields with 40-50 percent less irrigation water consumption than specified by norms. - Normalized energy consumption reduced by 30 percent relative to similar sites. - 300 ha of land protected or reclaimed from salinisation as a result of demonstration projects
Output targets 1.2: - At least 100 pump audits completed by project, including audits of 25 diesel pumps - 20 percent energy saving achieved by replacement and/or fixing of old pumps Output target 1.3: 1100 people directly benefiting from measures on renewable-energy water supply in remote locations
Output targets 2.1: - Less than 5 percent of water is lost between withdrawal and end use in Kaakhka. - Water supply reliability is increased, while 41 wells can be decommissioned. Direct energy savings of 486 MWh per year, and reduction of associated GHG emissions by 240 tonnes. - At least 1 similar project initiated in other similar (or mountainous areas) districts of Akhal and Balkan velayats of Turkmenistan.
Output target 2.2: - Testing of at least three types of materials for canal linings and pipes. Initiation of mass production of new materials and/or cost reduction by 20 percent of mass-producing existing materials, involving at least two types of products. - Domestic production and installation expanded by 50 percent for at least two types of technologies for canal linings, pipelines, or other materials to reduce losses of water in transit. New lining of at least 400 km of canals. Reduction of water losses from newly lined canals by more than 50 percent.
Output targets 3.1. At least 3 velayat Integrated Water Distribution Plans developed and submitted for approval, recommendations are developed for other 2 velayats (Lebap and Balkan)
Output indicators 3.2. - Key stakeholders/institutions with relevant mandates involved trained jointly by the MAWE/Project - 90% positive feedback from training participants
Output target 4.1: At least 3 acts related to pump audits, crop-specific irrigation norms, and water/energy saving practices (incl. irrigation infrastructure) to lead to GHG emission reduction developed and adopted in support of the new Water Code.
Output target 4.3: There is a formal commitment of the government to allocate resources for demonstrated by the project technologies (e.g. inclusion in state-funded programmes and budgets) (Yes/No).
Output target 4.4: Programme for water measurement is developed and made operational at focus demonstrational sites (Yes/No)

Results of Output targets 1.1. - Result achieved: Yields vary by crop types and low-water irrigation types. Crops harvested with sprinkler irrigation consumed in average around 35% less water than specified by norms while gave about 32% more yield. Drip irrigation results are even better with nearly 40% less water than specified by norms while around 54% more yield than with traditional furrow irrigation types. - Result achieved: Application of low-water irrigation systems by 30 percent normalized energy consumption at Geokdepe research site relative to similar sites. - Result not achieved, but progressing: The project took certain measures to combat salinization at Geokdepe 145 ha plot through improvements in drainage canals in 2016, construction of piped irrigation network in 2017, construction of low-water irrigation systems and planting some crops irrigated with efficient irrigation technologies in 2018. The project experts also provide advisory support and trainings to local farmers working at research site and other neighbouring farms on efficient water use and SLM techniques. All these activities will contribute to remediation of lands from salinization. Land rehabilitation and salinity reduction process normally takes several years, so project will be monitoring salinity level throughout the project lifetime.
Results of Output targets 1.2. - Result achieved: Project experts conducted audit of efficiency and energy consumption of 121 pumps including 46 diesel pumps in 2017. - Result not achieved, but progressing: Supplier contracted to replace five physically worn pumps by brand new energy efficient ones in 2019. Based on the average energy specifications of baseline pump-sets (about 100 kW) and new pumps (45 kW), it is expected to achieve approx. 50% energy saving.
Results of Output targets 1.3. - Result not achieved, but progressing: The tender for installation of renewable-energy applications of water pumping and purification is ready now for announcement. The total number of beneficiaries will exceed 1200 people.
Results of Output targets 2.1. - Result achieved: 15 km long water supply pipeline for the Kaahkha district successfully launched in 2018 and practically eliminated water loss between withdrawal and water treatment facilities. - Result achieved: As noted by local authorities recently built Kaahka water pipeline substantially increased reliability of water supply as previously earthen river course was frequently damaged by mudflows which often happen in mountainous regions. Based on the calculations of International Expert on GHG emission reduction, Kaahka water pipeline result in annual energy savings of about 1000 MWh, and reduction of associated GHG emissions by 785 tCO2/year. - Result not achieved, but progressing: Preliminary estimates display up to 50% of water economy, with lifetime direct GHG emission reductions from operation of the combined water supply system in Kaakhka town are anticipated at 15,694 tCO2. Given its high replication potential in the country, a dialogue with the government is now underway to upscale this water-energy nexus effect.
Results of Output targets 2.2. - Result not achieved: National and International Experts in Irrigation Canals are on board, so starting from early 2019 they will be actively engaged in activities on testing various canal lining materials and preparation of recommendations on industrial production of at least two types of products.
Results of Output targets 3.1. - Result not achieved, but progressing: In 2018 the project developed methodology on development of inter-farm water use plans. The project plans to test the methodology on the farms of selected private farmers. The outcome of these activities will be used for further works on development of integrated regional sustainable water management plans with consideration of SLM at the level of etraps (districts). Furthermore, initial results of low-water irrigation demonstrations complemented with land management techniques at Geokdepe green polygon can serve as foundation for development of Water Distribution Plans with proven water and land management practices.
Results of Output targets 3.2. - Result achieved: Nearly 150 national specialists representing Ministry of Agriculture and Water, Water Design Institute, Ministry of Nature Protection and farmers have been trained locally and abroad since the beginning of the project in various topics related to rational water management, energy efficient irrigation techniques, pump maintenance and SLM. Positive feedback rate from training participants is around 92%.
Results of Output targets 4.1. - Result not achieved, but progressing: The project developed four regulatory acts to support Water Code, including (i) operational regulations for pump stations; (ii) regulation for scheduled preventive maintenance and repair of water systems and facilities; (iii) technical regulations of irrigation infrastructure; and (iv) technical regulations of drainage infrastructure. The documents are currently under consideration of Ministry of Agriculture and Water Economy and other relevant state agencies.
Results of Output targets 4.3. - Result not achieved, but progressing: Following presidential order on development of the Water Development Program of Turkmenistan for 2018-2030, Ministry of agriculture and water economy and its Water Design Institute started working on the strategic development document from early 2018. Project experts who directly involved in creation of water saving Geokdepe research site provided advisory support with technical and financial justifications to government authorities to promote replication of Geokdepe site activities through inclusion of modern low-water irrigation systems to the Water Program. Currently, the final draft of the Program is under review of the top water sector authorities.
Results of Output targets 4.4. - Result achieved: Baseline data collection program for the Kaahka pilot project has been prepared and initiated in 2016 through installation of water measuring devices at the source and lower stream of the current open-water channel that supply drinking water to the town of Kaahka. These meters enabled the project to accurately measure and calculate the average monthly water flow. Water metering was further improved with construction of water distribution point as part of the Kaahka water pipeline project completed in April 2018. Testing of water measurement devices at Geokdepe demonstration site started in 2017 when piped irrigation network was built. Additional water meters were installed along with drip and sprinkler irrigation systems in June 2018 when collection of water consumption figures continued more intensively with planting of various crops.

Output target 2.2: - 2 production lines established (one for geomembrane and one for hexagonal precast concrete slabs) Output targets 3.1. At least 1 velayat Integrated Water Distribution and Management Plan developed and submitted for approval, recommendations are developed for other 2 velayats Output targets 3.2. • Key stakeholders/institutions with relevant mandates involved/trained jointly by the Project • 90% positive feedback from training participants Output targets 3.3 Project evaluation and compilation of lessons learned

description.narrative: Institutional CD for national policies of quality of education and the development of the evaluation indicators towards enhancing knowledge based Society
capital of a political entity
Adoption of the programme's draft terms of reference framework by the competent bodies, and Adoption of guidelines for the curricula programme

comment.narrative: Lack of a clear policy or accredited programmes in the field of education evaluation
Monitor RDIC & IT & SAQF projects risks and issues, and analyze its impact over the projects and the strategic plan

The Education and Training Evaluation Commission (ETEC) recently worked to remodel its organizational structure, which came in implementation of the Supreme Decisions for the establishment of the Commission and to integrate all sectors concerned with the evaluation of education and training and consolidate its work under its umbrella. "National Center for School Evaluation and Excellence", which undertakes the evaluation and accreditation of schools in the general education for both public and private schools. And the amendment of the name “National Center for Technical and Vocational Accreditation and Assessment” to “National Center for Assessment and Accreditation of Training” to include all programs Governmental and private, including technical education and vocational training sector and other government and private sectors. The project main objectives were to support the implementation of ETEC initiatives: • Data analytics / Artificial intelligence. • Curriculum Standards • Saudi Arabia Qualification Framework (SAQF) This project covered achievements on capacity development and required experience. In general, the project seems to be performing well as expected, and the results are mostly sustainable.
Standards-related teacher support tools developed and Teacher licensing regulation finalized and approved

This project is with the Education Training and Evaluation Commission and the UNDP. This project is the implementation of the priority strategic initiatives by hiring qualified human resources and EEC premises, providing consultancy services to implement initiatives, performance indicators, documentation, and achieving the intended objectives. Regarding teacher licensing, the project has provided bylaws, selected tools used for supporting teacher licensing, and standards that have been approved by the Board of Directors. By implementing teacher licensing this will ensure that school children will receive the quality education that every student deserves by hiring the qualified persons to do so.

description.narrative: -Reduction in GHG emissions from transport, public lighting, and hotel management, relative to baseline -Reduction in energy consumption from transport, public lighting, and hotel management, relative to baseline -Number of direct individual and institutional participants (including both women and men) in project-led initiatives on alternative transport, pilot waste sorting and reduction, and green hotel management

comment.narrative: 1.1 Reduction by 3 percent (180 million passenger-km per year) of private car travels via increased use of alternative modes of transportation and carpooling 1.2 Reduction of electricity consumption from public outdoor lighting by 1.5 million kWh per year in Ashgabat and 8 million kWh per year in whole Turkmenistan, compared to baseline 1.3 Reduction in landfill waste in Ashgabat and Avaza relative to baseline of recycling and waste reduction programs. Increase in recycling volume by 10 percent and increase in use of secondary raw materials by 25% 2.1 Improved capacities and enabling conditions in Avaza for integrated low-carbon and climate-resilient tourism development 2.2 Reduced GHG emissions and other negative environment impact through interventions involving tourism facilities and infrastructure in Avaza 3.1. Spreading of experience and increasing the volume of first two components of the project on nationwide level via spreading of information, capacity building of establishments and managers as well as adopting state policy and legal normative acts

1.1 Not achieved 1.2 Partially achieved 1.3 Partially achieved
(The Ministry of Transport – which was as a project partner responsible for sharing information with the project on the public transport routes to be optimized (which was reorganized in January 2019 – 5 months after the Inception Workshop - into Agency “TurkmenAvtoTransport” subordinated to the newly created Ministry of Industry and Communication, and then again in February 2020 reorganized as a separate Agency) is not engaging with the project despite numerous open channels of engagement and communication. Furthermore, Cities project and the Ministry of Energy of Turkmenistan has begun joint work on the introduction of new energy efficiency technologies into the electric networks of Ashgabat city through the supply of energy-saving equipment. New transformers with a voltage of 10/0.4 kV in amount of 60 pcs by UNDP and 360 pcs by Ministry will be installed in the electric networks of power consumers of newly connected settlements of the city of Ashgabat. Construction and installation works are planned to be carried out by divisions of the Ministry of Energy, and at the expense of the saved funds, it is planned to purchase cable products for the reconstruction of distribution electric networks. As a result of these works, along with improving the reliability of power supply to consumers, technological costs of electric energy on distribution electric networks will also decrease. The result of such practical cooperation between UNDP and the Ministry of Energy will be the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions of more than 500 000 tons of CO2. As a result of cooperation with the Ministry of Energy, a draft of a new Law of Turkmenistan "On Energy Saving and Energy Efficiency" and number of regulatory legal acts aimed at introducing the new energy efficiency technologies into production were jointly developed. Concurrently, joint work is underway on development of draft regulatory legal and regulatory technical documents on energy efficiency. In addition, new draft Law of Turkmenistan on “Renewable Energy” was developed. Project developed National Strategy of Turkmenistan on “Development of Renewable Energy” which was approved by the President of Turkmenistan on 4 December 2020. Moreover, Project jointly with the Nature Protection Society of Turkmenistan (NGO) launched second campaign on waste collection and sorting among residents of Ashgabat city. This time, campaign includes not only collection and sorting of plastic waste but also it covers paper and glass. It needs to be noted that the residents of the city have been actively taking part in this campaign in daily basis. Moreover, normative-regulatory document to the Law of Turkmenistan “On Waste” is being developed. At present, project is in the process of determining the pilot site for waste recycling and sorting with the Municipality of Ashgabat city. Due to the COVID-19, internal flights were restricted and thus, activities related to waste in Avaza are halted. Development of several normative technical documentation and regulatory legal acts to the Law of Turkmenistan "On waste" have been started by the initiative and support by UNDP Cities project. In addition, it supports the development of the draft of new National Strategy of Turkmenistan in the field of waste management as another step towards sustainability.)
2.1 Not achieved 2.2 Partially achieved
(Avaza Touristic Zone is closed by the government of Turkmenistan due to the COVID-19. Therefore, project is unable to get access to Avaza and implement its activities. However, Regardless of restrictions in Avaza, project switched its some activities to Ashgabat. The project has identified pilot hotel for conducting energy audit in «Grand Turkmen» hotel in Ashgabat. Related works on energy audit are being conducted with the involvement of project international consultant on energy audit and national consultants.)
3.1 Partially achieved
There were several articles published in various official and private newspaper, websites of the country. One of the prominent project activities that was highlighted by the government was the meeting of the Interdepartmental Working Group on the working out the National Strategy of Turkmenistan on the Development of Renewable Energy with the participation of project international and local specialists in a video conference format. Moreover, there are numerous articles on waste management regarding the second campaign on waste collection and sorting from population of Turkmenistan. Lastly, it needs to be underlined that the project assisted in procurement of air and water contamination monitoring equipment for Ecological Control Service of the Ministry of Agriculture and Environment Protection of Turkmenistan.

1.1. Energy-efficient street lighting implemented in Ashgabat and technical justification prepared 1.2. Development of sustainable urban transport solutions in Ashgabat to be approved by the city (in order to avoid spending funds for activities that have little chance to be ever implemented) or dropped from the list of project activities in case of zero engagement of the city authorities 1.3. Approval received from the city authorities to apply city plans for sustainable development to be designed by the Project 1.4. Volumes of waste fractions that can be recycled in a commercially viable and sustainable way are identified. Plans to introduce separate collection of these fractions are prepared and proved by the city authorities in Ashgabat. Different required stakeholders commit resources to a joint effort with the project being a liaison between the interested parties. The volume of recycling starts to increase in Ashgabat by year-end. 2.1 Practice on reducing energy consumption, water use, and waste implemented by at least one hotel in Avaza. 2.2 Demonstration and replication of solar-powered public lighting is made subject to the Ministry of Energy providing information on off-the-grid sites where such installations make economic sense and are sustainable from life-cycle-costing (LCC) perspective. 2.3 The city authorities in Avaza share information about traffic routes and commit to implement project’s recommendations regarding optimizing efficient surface transportation in Avaza 2.4 Managerial and technical capacity of planners, officials, and facility managers in Awaza enhanced via training 3.1 National policy developed and adopted in support of integrated and scaled-up "green" urban development practices. 3.2 The «Turkmen motor transport» agency of Ministry of Industry and Communications agrees to consider amending existing standards for fuel efficiency of imported cars in order to create incentives for a switch to higher fuel efficiency vehicles.

1.1 Partially achieved (More than 27,000 LED lamps and 28,000 LED luminaires were installed across Ashgabat using public funds following commitment to cooperate with the Project from the city authorities on LED lighting upgrade).
1.2 - Partially achieved. 1.3 - Partially achieved 1.4 - Partially achieved (The Project has suffered from a late actual project start: the activities began in July 2018 instead of December 2017 due to a change in the implementing partner. The downgrade of the original sponsor of the Project Document (Ministry of Environment) to the status of a committee within the Ministry of Agriculture has resulted in difficulties in project activities implementation. Also, there was a re-organization of other key national partner – the Ministry of Transport become as the Agency. The project is planning to resume political dialogue on transport and waste management issues in 2020. The project team has also prepared a plan to compensate for lack of cooperation of the two aforementioned actors by increasing its dialogue with the Ministry of Energy (to focus more on stimulating a transition to smart grid-related infrastructure investments).
2.1 - Partially achieved 2.2 - Partially achieved 2.3 - Partially achieved ( The hotel complex initially selected for the audit rejected the Project’s offer for a free audit. The Project is now focusing on liaising with another hotel complex owned by another stakeholder (Ministry of Energy) that is more committed to Project Document objectives (a transition to smart grid).
2.4 - Accomplished. (On 6 November 2019 Project held seminar-training on “Possibility of reduction of energy consumption at hotels of National Touristic Zone “Avaza”” for related specialists of government organizations and hotel representatives).
3.1 - Partially achieved 3.2 - Partially achieved (The Project has faced stiff resistance from the initially well-subscribed stakeholders (mayoral office of Ashgabat and the Ministry of Transport) to pilot any initiatives proposed in the Project Document. The Project Team is now working successfully with the Ministry of Energy on piloting street lighting projects. The Project is therefore planning to invest available resources to develop national policies in assisting the Ministry of Energy in its ongoing renewable energy and smart grid development work.).

-Savings of 80,000 tonnes of CO2 emissions achieved via project interventions by end of year 3 -Energy savings of 1350 TJ across all sectors achieved by the end of year 3 -Confirmed participation by at least 5,000 citizens (2,500 women and girls)

El objetivo del proyecto es desarrollar mecanismos innovadores para el incremento de los beneficios ambientales y el crecimiento sostenible en Uruguay, generando sinergias con las tres Convenciones de Río.
capital of a political entity
Las OSC y autoridades de Uruguay desarrollan un marco de colaboración para integrar esfuerzos hacia el cumplimiento de las Convenciones

comment.narrative:
Uruguay está comprometido a adoptar un enfoque innovador y transformador para cumplir con las obligaciones de las Convenciones de Río dentro de los marcos ambientales actuales
Las capacidades nacionales para implementar las Convenciones de Río no son sostenibles en la actualidad, y por lo general requieren del apoyo financiero de donantes
Los compromisos para implementar las Convenciones de Río son medidos principalmente a través de instrumentos específicos para las Convenciones de Río

Evaluación del estado de situación y cumplimiento de las Convenciones de Río.
Lanzamiento de una convocatoria a grupos de base comunitario para la presentación de proyectos de gestión ambiental relacionados con el cumplimiento de las convenciones de Río en la región este.

Documentos con la evaluación del estado de cumplimiento por parte de Uruguay de las Convenciones de Río (Biodiversidad, Degradación de Suelos y Cambio Climático) elaborado.
Se elaboraron las bases de la convocatoria para proyectos de gestión ambiental dirigidos a grupos de base comunitaria. Se acordó la estrategia para dicha convocatoria en conjunto con el Programa de Pequeñas Donaciones (MVOTMA/MINTUR/PNUD/FMAM). Se publicó la convocatoria y se evaluaron los perfiles de proyectos recibidos.

Desarrollo de mecanismos e instrumentos innovadores para aumentar los beneficios ambientales globales y al crecimiento sostenible
Mejora de la coordinación de los Puntos Focales (PF) en relación con el enfoque transversal.
Las instituciones relevantes mejoran la integración y las sinergias en relación al cambio climático, la biodiversidad y la degradación de la tierra.
Las Organizaciones de la Sociedad Civil contribuyen al diálogo y a la construcción de capacidades intersectoriales.
Las Organizaciones de la Sociedad Civil aportan análisis independientes e información en relación a los beneficios y compromisos relativos a las Convenciones de Río
Se establece una plataforma de conocimiento para recopilar, difundir y compartir información sobre temas vinculados a las Convenciones
Apoyo al proceso de descentralización para la incorporación de las Convenciones de río a la planificación y la toma de decisiones locales

Políticas de Co Gestión: Funcionamiento del Comité Directivo de forma regular y con alta concurrencia de sus miembros. Aprobación de los temas a tratar por consenso. Funcionamiento de los grupos de trabajo establecidos entre los PFs y entre estos y las las OSC y las OSC entre sí. Coordinacion de politicas de gestion ambiental entre los gobiernos locales y el gobierno central (Dinama). Fortalecimiento de redes de trabajo para la gestión socio-ambiental local. Creación conjunta de una matriz de integración de las tres convenciones para realizar política y gestión ambiental.
Se han mantenido las reuniones formales y continuas entre los Puntos Focales del MVOTMA y entre éstos y las OSC monitoras de las convenciones. Los talleres realizados y ya referenciados, tanto por OSC como por PFs, han todos contribuido a enriquecer el enfoque transversal.
Las direcciones de Desarrollo de las Intendencias de la región Este se han integrado a ECCOSUR con un buen involucramiento, participando de la mayoría de las instancias de capacitación e intercambio convocadas por el proyecto. Como se mencionó anteriormente la participación ha sido de forma dispar, debido a la disparidad en sus capacidades y el perfil de sus referentes. Se detecta un mayor involucramiento y aprovechamiento del proyecto cuando el referente es un técnico en lugar de un político. El INC incorpora criterios ambientales para sus predios según surge del Acuerdo con Aves Uruguay ya referenciado. Referentes territoriales del MGAP participan de capacitaciones de ECCOSUR. Al menos 4 referentes territoriales del MGAP y 2 del INC se han capacitado en temáticas de las Convenciones de Río, género y gobernanza.
Vida Silvestre, Ceuta y CIEDUR avanzan en la elaboración de la matriz de integración de las Convenciones de Río, convocando a especialistas, los PFs, intendencias y demás actores relevantes para aportar y validar la herramienta. Se realiza seguimiento integral y sinérgico de las 3 Convenciones, como también evaluaciones y recomendaciones técnicas. Aves Uruguay capacita a colonos y técnicos del INC en elementos básicos del pastoreo racional, para una mejor incorporación de dimensiones ambientales en el manejo de los predios
El equipo de trabajo permanente integrado por CIEDUR, CEUTA y Vida Silvestre continúa trabajando y se ha fortalecido mejorando el seguimiento integrado de las Convenciones así como el diálogo y discusión permanente con los PF
Se continúa trabajando con la herramienta del “Observatorio Ambiental de la DINAMA” como plataforma de conocimiento permanente para recopilar, difundir y compartir información. Las OSC del proyecto firman un acuerdo para crear el OICR. Ecos AC produce audiovisuales los proyectos locales de Eccosur, apoyando la difusión de las acciones en territorio
Se ha generado un vínculo fluido con las Divisiones de Desarrollo de los gobiernos Rocha, Lavalleja y Treinta y Tres, con sus referentes como claros interlocutores aportando al proyecto. También la intendencia de Maldonado desde la División de Medio Ambiente. Asimismo, se ha logrado el acuerdo con el CURE y la ejecución de 15 proyectos llevados adelante por OSC en el territorio. Como se ha mencionado previamente, para llegar a esto, se trabajó capacitando a las organizaciones, asistiendo en el desarrollo de sus proyectos y fomentando el intercambio entre pares.

description.narrative: Promoting mini-hydro and integrated watershed management to increase grid/isolated-grid/small hydropower capacity
capital of a political entity

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

receiver-org.narrative: Government of Sao Tome and Principe
Government of Sao Tome and Principe

description.narrative: Addressing the barriers to significantly increase grid/isolated-grid-connected mini/small hydropower capacity and to sustainably manage the watershed

comment.narrative:
GHG emissions in the electricity generation sector has increased from 79,080 tons in 1998 to 101,480 tons in 2005. This increase is getting bigger due to a sustained increase in diesel fuel use for electricity generation. The present contribution of hydropower in the electricity generation mix of the country was a mere 8 % in 2013. No investment taking place in the grid/non-grid-connected mini hydropower sector.
No IWMPs are yet developed in the country. No lands restoration techniques implemented in STP. A loss of approx. 1,515 tCO2 every year in the 6,000 ha of forest in the project sites. No large-scale reforestation driven by the GoSTP (private initiative exists, for a commercial purpose).
Solutions développées en matière de l'efficacité du secteur de l'énergie renouvelable

Appui technique et consultatif pour le renforcement de secteurs clés (Direction générale des ressources naturelles et énergie (DRNE), Direction d’appui au développement de l’Agriculture (DADA), Direction des forêts (DIFO), Autorité Général de Régulation (AGR), Entreprise nationale de l´eau et électricité (EMAE) pour le développement des secteurs hydrologique et agricole.

In a first phase, preparation of the legal and regulatory environment for investors to enter the energy market. In a second phase, investing in solutions for the efficiency of the renewable energy sector.

Technical and advisory support for the strengthening of key sectors (Directorate General of Natural Resources and Energy (DRNE), Directorate for Support to Agricultural Development (DADA), Directorate of Forests (DIFO), General Regulatory Authority (AGR) National Water and Electricity Enterprise (EMAE) for the development of the hydrological and agricultural sectors.

sector.narrative: Eradicate poverty in all its forms and dimensions

description.narrative: 1) Non-incineration and Mercury-free technologies introduced in African countries. Affordable non-incineration technologies available in the African region. 2) UPOPs releases from the health sector reduced or avoided 3) Mercury releases from the health sector reduced 4) Country capacity built to effectively phase out and reduce releases of POPs 5) Mid-term evaluation criteria and formula for the allocation of technologies among countries available 6) A teams of 4 national experts (16 in total for the four countries) trained at regional level 7) Number of national HCWM strategies, policies, action plans as well as number of drafts for HCWM related standards and guidelines available. 8) Number of National Action Plans for project implementation available 9)Number of Non-incineration HCWM systems and Hg free devices procured. 10) Number of HCWM systems installed and Hg-free devices distributed 11) Number of project HCFs that have introduced BEP. 12) Number of project HCFs that have introduced BEP. Number of HCF staff trained in BEP & BAT. Number of project HCFs that have operational BAT. Number of project HCFs that have recycling programmes in place. No. of project countries that have storage sites for phase-out Hg-containing devices. Number of Mercury-free project HCFs. Number of institutions that offer HCWM training/certificate courses. 13) Evaluation report (including recommendations for each project country and HCF) available. Number of HCWM systems and Hg free devices procured 14) Number of HCFs supported in addition to the initial set of HCFs. Number of Mercury-free project HCFs in addition to the initial set. 15) Number of people trained in addition to the initial set of trained HCF personnel. List of environment and health conferences in the region 16) Number of high quality monitoring and evaluation documents prepared during project implementation

comment.narrative: 1) In 2012, there were approximately 115 non-incineration HCW technologies installed throughout Africa. In the project countries, 3 working hydroclaves have been installed in Ghana (April 2014). Affordable non-incineration technologies are not available to African HCFs 2) UPOPs baseline: Ghana: 19.8 g-TEQ/yr (pre-selected hospitals) Mercury baseline: Ghana: 8.2 kg/yr (pre-selected hospitals) 3) The regulatory, policy framework not current, national implementation plan not operational and No standard exist in medical waste management Ghana. 4) Evaluation criteria and allocation of technologies among project countries not in place. Some knowledge on Mercury and UPOPs releases from the health sector built during the PPG phase. 5) In each of the project countries the baseline pertaining to the HCWM policy and regulatory framework is different. For Ghana the situation is summarized on page 20 in the section “National Policy regulatory and legal Framework on HCWM in Ghana” Draft National Action Plans for project implementation available. Pre-selection of HCFs has already taken place. 6) Three (3) BAT in 3 pre-selected HCFs and none (0) BEP in place at most of the model HCFs. No recycling programmes in place at any of the HCFs. No storage sites for Mercury or Medical devices containing Mercury available in any of the project countries. In Ghana, some project HCFs already uses some Mercury-free medical devices, but none of the pre-selected HCFs is Mercury-free. In Ghana, training programme for waste management exists, but training programmes for HCWM need to be established/improved

1)Number of Ministries and Agencies engaged for the finalization of the Policy and Guideline. 2)Number of Policy and Guidelines printed 3) Number of policy dissemination meetings held 4) Number of recycling companies engaged 5) Number of temporary storages constructed for Ghana as interim storage for mercury-containing devices 6) Quantities of mercury-containing devices collected and stored 7) Number of new facilities selected for the second phase 8) Number of new health facilities attached to the first phase facilities to operate a cluster system 9)Number of additional mercury-free devices procured and exchanged with mercury-containing ones 10) Number of trainings conducted for health staff and operators on healthcare waste management. 11) Number of lessons learnt and best practices documented; 12) Number of abstracts submitted for participation in environmental conferences in the Africa region

1) Directors of the PPME, Legal Unit and the Chief Director of Ministry of Health were engaged to have a final review of the policy and guidelines. This was followed by a final review by the Minister for Health who reviewed and passed the documents for printing.Prior to this, key directors in GHS, ESPA, MESTI and EPA reviewed and shared final inputs in the policy and guidelines for finalization. 2&3) WHO has produced dummy copies for final review. Launching and dissemination of revised policy and guidelines is planned for 2020. 4)There is little or no presence of recyclers of plastics in the project areas. So far, only one scrap dealer has expressed willingness to explore the possibilities of recycling the sharp waste generated from the health facilities. 5)Collaborated with GHS and MoH to construct the facility. However, this discussion could not progress due to institutional bottlenecks at EPA (The national focal point on mercury expected to provide technical guidance). Discussion ongoing to have a solution in 2020 through the intervention of UNDP. 6) Procurement process being done by UNDP was uncompleted as at the end of the year. This process is expected to be completed in the first part of 2020. 7)3 new HCF facilities selected for the second phase of the project, namely: Korle Bu Teaching Hospital, Dua Yaw Nkwanta St. John of God Hospital and the Greater Accra Regional Hospital. They will be provided with logistics and capacity building to improve healthcare waste management in their facilities. Only Dua Yaw Nkwanta St. John of God Hospital however will receive an autoclave in January 2020. 8) Draft MoUs are being discussed between the Phase 1 facilities and new facilities identified in the operation area. MOUs expected to be signed in 2020 to initiate operation. Number of new facilities identified for each of the model facilities yet to be confirmed after MOU signing. 9) Procurement processes still ongoing. hence exchange of additional mercury free devices programme yet to be implemented. Good to note that this process has been conducted between UNDP/MOH/GHS to ensure that the national systems fully participate in this process to enhance ownership and learning.In addition to this a draft national strategy for mercury phaseout in the health sector has been developed to provide strategic direction on mercury phaseout activities towards the 2025 deadline under the Minamata Convention. Model facilities of the project have also been supported to develop an exit strategy which include a plan for mercury phaseout in their health facilities. Additional funding has been approved through the Minamata SIP to support additional phaseout programmes in 2020. 10) -a. This training could not take place due to the delay in the installation of the autoclave equipment at Dua Yaw Nkwanta Hospital. The technicians from the suppliers are expected to deliver this training in 2020. -b. Four quarterly trainings was conducted in all model facilities on HCWM and data management. This has contributed to increased segregation and management of HCWM data for planning. -c. One modular course training was organised in Ho School of Hygiene. A total of 26 participants were trained through the Modular short course on HCWM. This is to increase the availability of technical experts at the national level to lead the mainstreaming of HCWM at various levels. -d. Curriculum review on-going in collaboration with Ministry of Health and UBORA Institute. It is expected to be completed in January 2020. 11) Documentation of lessons learnt and best practices on-going. One impact story has been drafted and being reviewed. The project facilitated a learning visit from personnel from Uganda MOH, to learn about HCWM systems being established here in Ghana for replication in Uganda. 12) Two case studies have been developed and shared widely to stakeholders. One of these abstracts was accepted by the Global Green and Health Hospitals, culminating in Ghana’s participation in the GGHH regional conference in Durban, South Africa;
1. HCWM policy and guidelines disseminated 2. One autoclave installed. 3. 50 HCF staff of the additional HCFs trained in BEP/BAT
1. 5 autoclaves installed and operational. 2. National modular course on health care waste management developed. 3. Project mid-term evaluation conducted.

1. 5 JSD 250l autoclaves were installed in 3 health care facilities (two for Cape Coast Teaching Hospital, two for Eastern Regional Hospital and one for Tebgi Health Center). The provision of the autoclave treatment technologies and the training provided to health care staff (350 people) in the 5 pilot facilities has contributed to building national capacity to implement best techniques in the management of healthcare waste to eliminate the emission of Unintended Persistent Organic Pollutants like dioxins and furans into the environment, as required by the Stockholm Convention. In the long run, it will contribute to improvement in healthcare delivery which will reduce the exposure to infections on patients, health staff and nearby communities.
2. A national modular course for health care waste management has been established at the Accra School of Hygiene. The objective is to create a system to provide capacity building opportunities for healthcare waste managers and practitioners. 26 trainees ranging from health care workers, environmental health officers and consultants from civil society were trained in 2018 to contribute to already existing capacity in health facilities to manage healthcare waste in an environmentally sound manner.
3. The Project Mid-Term Evaluation was conducted. Its findings are being taken into consideration in the planning of the second phase of the project, starting in 2020.
